Message.Issue: Mark 'School.Model.dll' with CLSCompliant(true) because it exposes externally visible types.

Because 'School.Model.dll' exposes externally visible types, mark it with ComVisible(false) at the assembly level and then mark all types within the assembly that should be exposed to COM clients with ComVisible(true).

'Course.Course()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Course..ctor() Course.set_Students(List<Student>):Void

'Course.Course(int, string)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Course..ctor(Int32, String) Course.set_Students(List<Student>):Void
Change 'Course.Students' to be read-only by removing the property setter.

'Student.Student()' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Student..ctor() Student.set_Courses(List<Course>):Void

'Student.Student(int, string, string)' contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences:
Student..ctor(Int32, String, String) Student.set_Courses(List<Course>):Void
Change 'Student.Courses' to be read-only by removing the property setter.

Rule.Name: Collection properties should be read only
Rule.Description: Properties that return collections should be read-only so that users cannot entirely replace the backing store. Users can still modify the contents of the collection by calling relevant methods on the collection. Note that the XmlSerializer class has special support for deserializing read-only collections. See the XmlSerializer overview for more information.
Rule.Resolution: Change {0} to be read-only by removing the property setter.

Rule.Name: Do not call overridable methods in constructors
Rule.Description: Virtual methods defined on the class should not be called from constructors. If a derived class has overridden the method, the derived class version will be called (before the derived class constructor is called).
Rule.Resolution: {0} contains a call chain that results in a call to a virtual method defined by the class. Review the following call stack for unintended consequences: {1}

Rule.Name: Mark assemblies with CLSCompliantAttribute
Rule.Description: Assemblies should explicitly state their CLS compliance using the CLSCompliant attribute. An assembly without this attribute is not CLS-compliant. Assemblies, modules, and types can be CLS-compliant even if some parts of the assembly, module, or type are not CLS-compliant. The following rules apply: 1) If the element is marked CLSCompliant, any noncompliant members must have the CLSCompliant attribute present with its argument set to false. 2) A comparable CLS-compliant alternative member must be supplied for each member that is not CLS-compliant.
Rule.Resolution: Mark {0} with CLSCompliant(true) because it exposes externally visible types.

Rule.Name: Mark assemblies with ComVisibleAttribute
Rule.Description: The System.Runtime.InteropServices.ComVisible attribute indicates whether COM clients can use the library. Good design dictates that developers explicitly indicate COM visibility. The default value for this attribute is 'true'. However, the best design is to mark the assembly ComVisible false, and then mark types, interfaces, and individual members as ComVisible true, as appropriate.
Rule.Resolution: Because {0} exposes externally visible types, mark it with ComVisible(false) at the assembly level and then mark all types within the assembly that should be exposed to COM clients with ComVisible(true).
